**Greenland Urged to Rejoin EU to 'Protect' Against Trump's Threats**
A Danish member of the European Parliament, Morten Lekkegaard, has called on Greenland to consider rejoining the European Union for 'protection' against the threats of new US President Donald Trump. Lekkegaard acknowledged that Greenland's future ultimately lies in the hands of the Greenlandic people, but argued that it's time for 'new thinking'. 'We live in a world where, no matter how independent you want to be, you need to be a member of alliances,' he said. 'And in my opinion, the EU is the best alliance you can join. This applies to Denmark, this applies to Greenland.' Lekkegaard believes that being part of the EU would provide Greenland with protection. Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark, voted to leave the European Communities, a precursor to the EU, in a referendum in 1982 and officially left the bloc in 1985. However, most of its approximately 60,000 citizens are Danish and therefore remain EU citizens. 'It's clear that the situation has changed dramatically since 1985,' Lekkegaard said. Additionally, Greenland has a strong movement for independence, with Prime Minister Mute Egede calling for the island's separation from Denmark. 'We don't want to be Danes. We don't want to be Americans. We want to be Greenlanders,' he said in an interview earlier this month. It's worth noting that Donald Trump has stated that control over Greenland is 'absolutely necessary' for the United States, and that the US does not rule out the possibility of using force to annex the island.

However, the crisis has also led to a re-evaluation of the relationship between Denmark and Greenland, with the Greenlandic government gaining more autonomy and influence on the international stage. The Danish government has also agreed to suspend the controversial 'FKU' tests, which have been a source of tension between the two countries. The tests, which evaluate a parent's ability to care for their children, have been criticized for being culturally insensitive and have led to the removal of many children from their families. The Greenlandic government has long been seeking to abolish the tests, and the crisis has given them a newfound sense of confidence and autonomy. 'We are not Danish, but we do not want to be American either,' said Greenland's Prime Minister Mute Egede. 'We want to be independent and make our own decisions.' The crisis has also highlighted the cultural differences between Denmark and Greenland, with many Greenlanders feeling that they are treated as second-class citizens by the Danish government. 'We are two different countries, and the ultimate goal is independence,' said Najannguac Dalgard Christensen, a Greenlandic politician. 'The reality is that we are two countries with different cultures and values, and it's time for us to take control of our own destiny.'

**Greenland's Quest for Independence: A Response to Trump's Ambitions**
The ambitions of US President Donald Trump to annex Greenland have caused a major diplomatic crisis for Denmark. The relations between the new administration in Washington and the Danish government are at an all-time low after Trump's aggressive conversation with Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen, in which he expressed that the US needs to control Greenland. According to sources, the conversation was 'horrible' and 'very tough', and Trump again threatened to impose specific tariffs on the Scandinavian country. Despite the tense relations, the Danish government is trying to show unity with the autonomous government of Nuuk, announcing several social measures and investments to strengthen the military presence and surveillance in the Arctic island. Frederiksen is also trying to gain the support of her European partners, saying that 'European unity has never been more important'. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz has condemned any territorial expansion, saying 'borders should not be moved by force'. Meanwhile, the focus on the island's media and Trump's desires for annexation have fueled arguments in favor of independence and the debate on a referendum on self-determination that could be held in the next few years. The Greenlandic government has shown a good disposition to strengthen ties with Washington, but a majority of the parties in the Inatsisartut (the Greenlandic Parliament) have rejected the idea of the US taking control of the island. Instead, a majority of the parties support a future independent Greenland, and the dispute between the US and Denmark seems to have accelerated this process. The Greenlandic government has started working on creating a framework for independence, and a referendum on self-determination is expected to be held in the next four years. According to a study by the University of Copenhagen, seven out of ten Greenlanders would vote in favor of emancipation from the Kingdom of Denmark. One of the key issues in a future referendum on independence will be establishing how long Denmark will continue to subsidize the government of Nuuk. Currently, a third of the public sector in Greenland is financed by an annual contribution from Copenhagen of 4.1 billion kroner (500 million euros). The Danish government also handles justice, police, the prison system, and the surveillance of the territorial waters, as well as having the competences of defense and security of the island. The discovery of natural resources such as rare earth minerals and oil and gas deposits represents a hope for Greenland to leave its economic dependence on Copenhagen's aid, which maintains the current welfare state system. However, economist Torben Andersen from the University of Aarhus notes that 'until now, no large mining projects have been put into operation, while the prospect of extracting millions of barrels of oil has been buried by the enormous costs of doing so in the Arctic'. 'With the most optimistic glasses, it is unlikely that mining will be economically significant for Greenland in a 10-year horizon', concludes Andersen.
